translated: Translation: Tripiá¹­aka Master from the Song Dynasty, Volume 10 of the Record of the Three Treasures Through the Ages, Translated Scriptures, Song Dynasty
Submitted by the Translator-in-Chief, Subject Fei Changfang, in the 17th year of the Kaihuang era
The Song Dynasty records: Liu Yu, whose courtesy name was De Yu, was a person from Du Xiang in Pengcheng. When he was born,
the divine light illuminated the room.
He was seven chi and six cun tall.
He received the abdication of the Eastern Jin and called himself the Song Emperor.
He still had his capital in Jiankang.
By the third year of the Yuanjia era,
there were those who reported to him, saying:
The temples and pagodas are too extravagant and ostentatious.
The followers who delight in creating blessings compete with each other in extravagance day by day.
Emperor Wen asked He Shichang:
Fan Tai and Xie Lingyun all say that the Six Classics are originally for governing the people.
They consider the Buddhist scriptures to be the guide for understanding the true essence of human nature and destiny.
These words of the wise and accomplished are indeed sincere and reasonable.
If the people of the whole country were all pure in this practice,
then I, the Emperor, could sit with folded arms and achieve a peaceful and prosperous age.ğŸ”½Shang Zhi replied:
Your Majesty's words are indeed true.
It is difficult to know everything that happened in the Central Plains after that.ğŸ”½Since crossing the river, Wang Dao was the foremost among the chief ministers.
Wang Meng and Xie Shang were the foremost among the literati.
Wang Bi, He Yan, and Wang Mi, etc.
Some were called outstanding,
some were called unrivaled.
Briefly counting dozens of people, all were outstanding.
There was no shortage of faithful Buddhists at that time.
Master Huiyuan said:
The teachings of Buddhism are indispensable in governing the people.
I think this statement accords with the profound principles. Why is it so? In a village of a hundred households, if ten people observe the five precepts, then ten people will be pure and respectful.
In a town of a thousand households, if a hundred people practice the ten wholesome deeds, then a hundred people will be harmonious and orderly.
If this wind of teaching is spread throughout the country,
and the households number in the millions, then there will be a million benevolent people.
If one can practice one good deed, then one evil deed will be eliminated.
If one evil deed is eliminated, then one punishment will be stopped.
One punishment is stopped in the family.
Ten thousand punishments are stopped in the country.
Then the words of Your Majesty will sit and bring about great peace.
Therefore, when Fotudeng entered Yecheng,
the killing and slaughter of the Shi clan was reduced by half.
The precious pagoda in Weichi emitted light.
Fu Jian pushed the saw to rest.
Meng Xun turned to bite without intimacy, and was as cruel as a tiger.
At the end of his life, he changed his understanding and became a good person.
The power of Fadao's way was equal to that of ten thousand men.
He almost disturbed the Wei River and the Wei River, but he was willing to die and go to the teacher's difficulties.
How is this not the inner transformation being applied?
At that time, Yang Xuanbao, the Gentleman-attendant in the Ministry of Personnel,
was sitting and said:
Your subject is afraid that the methods of Qin and Zhao for strengthening their armies,
and the plans of Sun and Wu for swallowing each other,
will not be taken from this.
The Emperor said:
This is not a tool for the Warring States period.
It is exactly as you say.
Shang Zhi said:
If you honor the hidden and secluded, then the warriors will be lazy.
If you value benevolence and virtue, then the military spirit will decline.
If you take Sun and Wu as your mind,
His intention is to devour.
He also does not take the way of Yao and Shun.
How can it be only the teachings of ÅšÄkyamuni?
The emperor was delighted and said:
In the Buddhist order, you are like Zilu in the teachings of Confucius.
So-called bad words do not enter the ears.
Judging from this, the discussion can be said to be ultimate.
The Dharma is manifested through people.
The Buddha entrusted the emperors.
From this point on, the Buddhist teachings flourished in the Song Dynasty.
Famous monks and scholars were as numerous as rice and hemp.
Precious temples and golden wheels were as dense as bamboo and reeds.
Successive eight rulers for fifty-nine years.
Among the translators, there were twenty-three monks and laypeople from China and India.
They produced sÅ«tras, vinaya, precepts, karman, upadeÅ›a, abhidharma treatises, and records.
A total of two hundred and ten texts in four hundred and ninety scrolls.
It is concluded as the Jiankang Record of the Song Dynasty.
Song monk Buddhabhadra

Buddhabhadra's MahÄ«Å›Äsaka Vinaya in thirty-four fascicles, seen in the Song and Qi catalogues by Dao'an.

A separate record says twenty-four fascicles, but this is likely a mistake. MahÄ«Å›Äsaka PrÄtimoká¹£a in one fascicle, seen in the catalogue by Zhu Daozu. MahÄ«Å›Äsaka Karman in one fascicle, seen in the catalogue by Zhu Daozu. The above three parts total thirty-six fascicles.
During the reign of Emperor Fei, King of Yingyang.
Buddhabhadra, a Tripiá¹­aka master from KaÅ›mÄ«ra, a Vinaya teacher.
In Chinese, Jue Shou.
In his youth, he studied under the MahÄ«Å›Äsaka school.
He was especially diligent in the Vinaya and also understood the essentials of meditation.
In the first year of Jingping, in the seventh month, he arrived in Yangdu.
Previously, Faxian obtained the original Sanskrit text of the MahÄ«Å›Äsaka Vinaya in the country of lions.
But he had not yet translated it.
And Faxian passed away.
The monks in the capital heard that BuddhajÄ«va was skilled in this study.
Therefore, the assembly discussed and invited him to translate it.
In the eleventh month of that year, they gathered at Longguang Temple.
It was translated into thirty-four fascicles.
BuddhajÄ«va held the Sanskrit text.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a Zhizeng of Yutian translated the language.ğŸ”½The Å›ramaá¹‡a Zhu Daosheng of Longguang Temple.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a Huieyan of Dong'an Temple and others.
Took turns in writing it down.
Examined the true meaning of the text.
Wang Lian of Langya, who was the same as the attendant, was the donor.
It was completed in the twelfth month of the second year.
He also extracted the essence of the precepts and the text of the karman from the great collection.
They are all practiced in the world.
2. The Sutra of Universal Radiance Adorned with Wisdom, 8 fascicles, second translation.
Same text as the one translated in Shu by Dharmaraká¹£a, but slightly different.
Seen in the records of Song, Qi, and the biographies of Dao'an and Sengzhao.

The Sutra of the Bodhisattva's Necklace of Past Activities, 2 fascicles. The Sutra of the Samadhi of Vairocana, 2 fascicles. The story of the layman Ming entering concentration.
Seen in the Eastern Records.

In the fourth year of Emperor Wen's Yigong era.
Åšramaá¹‡a Shi Zhiyan of Liangzhou.
At the age of twenty, he left home and traveled around to study widely.
He then encountered the previous sÅ«tras in Sanskrit in the Western Regions and brought them back to Yangdu.
Together with Baoyun, he translated them at Zhiyuan Temple.
Zhiyan's spiritual virtues are fully recorded in the Biographies of Eminent Monks.
They will not be repeated here.
Baoyun's Fufazang Jing in six fascicles is seen in Li Ku's catalog, Fosuoxingzan Jing in five fascicles was translated at Liuheshan Temple.

The Sanskrit original.
Seen in Zhu Daosheng's Records of the Song and Qi Dynasties and the Biographies of Eminent Monks. The four texts above total fifteen volumes.
In the era of Emperor Wen.
The Liangzhou monk Bao'en.
In his youth, he traveled to the West.
Proficient in Sanskrit writing and language.
The scripts and sounds of the countries of India.
He understood them all thoroughly.
Later, he returned to Chang'an and then to the south of the Yangtze River.
The scriptures he translated later were mostly revised by Bao'en.
Chinese and foreign languages were both mastered, and the pronunciation was correct.
Everyone had faith in him.
At that time, in Guanzhong, there was Zhu Fonian who was good at translation.
For two generations, he alone held the title.
He was the foremost in understanding the true scriptures.
In the Jiangzuo region, in translating and transmitting from Sanskrit to Song, none surpassed him.
At first, he worked together with Zhiyan.
After Zhiyan passed away, Yun later promoted it alone.
Therefore, it is not recorded much.

They considered that the chapters and sections of MÃ³cÄnjÄ«'s NirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra were sparse and concise.
Beginners found it difficult to grasp.
He then relied on the old translation of the Nirvana Sutra and added chapter titles to the original text.
The text had some excessive passages, which he also revised.
It was compiled into 36 fascicles.
At first, only a few copies were circulated and not widely.
Later, one time during the night, Yan suddenly had a dream in which he saw a person with an extremely large physical appearance.
He then spoke to Yan in a very loud voice, saying:
Why do you rashly make light changes to the revered Nirvana Sutra?
After Yan woke up, he felt uneasy in his heart.
In the morning, he gathered the monks and wanted to revise the previous version.
At that time, there were those who knew and all agreed to stop, saying:
This is probably just to warn and encourage future people.
If you must insist on going against reason,
how could it be possible to have a dream immediately after?
Yan considered it to be so.
Soon after, he had another dream in which a divine person told him:
Because of your power in propagating the sutra,
in the future you will definitely get to see the Buddha.
Fearing that future sages would not know the origin,
he therefore recorded it again.

In the era of Emperor Wen.
The foreign Å›ramaá¹‡a I-ye-po-luo.

He translated it in Pengcheng for Wang Zhongde, the Prefect of Northern Xu Prefecture.
When he reached the chapter on selection, he encountered obstacles and was unable to finish, so he stopped.
Guá¹‡abhadra translated the Bodhisattva Good Precepts SÅ«tra in twenty fascicles at Qihuan Temple.
The second translation, in eight fascicles, is slightly different from that translated by Dharmaká¹£ema.
It is seen in the records of Zhu Daosheng and the Biographies of Eminent Monks.
Later, his disciples continued to translate two chapters at Dinglin Temple.
It became thirty fascicles. Miscellaneous Abhidharma-há¹›daya in thirteen fascicles. I-ye-po-luo first translated it up to the chapter on selection, but stopped.
It is now continued and translated, totaling thirty-three fascicles.

It is the same as that translated by Tan Di of the Wei dynasty.

See the Biographies of Eminent Monks, Miscellaneous Records, and Baochang's Catalog, etc. Abridged Treatise on the Five Precepts for UpÄsakas, 1 fascicle, translated at Jianyuan Temple in the 8th year of the Yuanjia era.

Also called Abridged Treatise on the Five Precepts.
Seen in the Biographies of Eminent Monks and Baochang's Catalog. Twenty-two Precepts for Good Faith, 1 fascicle, also called The Twenty-two Precepts for Celibate UpÄsakas and UpÄsikÄs,

The Tripiá¹­aka Master from KaÅ›mÄ«ra, Guá¹‡abhadra.
In Chinese, it means Meritorious Armor.
In the Yuanjia years, he arrived in Jianye.
Emperor Wen received him with sincere inquiries.
The Emperor said,
I always wish to observe the precepts and abstain from killing,
but I am constrained by my body and cannot fulfill my wishes.
Since the Dharma Master has come from ten thousand li away to spread the Dharma in this country,
What can I use to teach them?
VarmÄ said:
The Way lies in the mind, not in external matters.
The Dharma depends on oneself, not on others.
Moreover, what emperors cultivate is different from what ordinary people cultivate.
Ordinary people have lowly status and inferior names, and their words are not authoritative.
If they do not restrain themselves and suffer hardship, what can they do?
Emperors take the four seas as their home and the myriad people as their children.
If they issue one fine statement, then officials and commoners are all delighted.
If they implement one good policy, then people and spirits are harmonious.
Punishments do not take innocent lives.
Labor does not exhaust people's strength.
This causes wind and rain to come at the right times, and cold and warmth to be in accord with the seasons.
The hundred grains flourish, and mulberries and hemp grow luxuriantly.
If one observes the fast like this, the fast is also great.
Not killing is also abundant.
How can it be that one must reduce one's half-day meal and spare the life of a single bird in order to be considered greatly compassionate?
The emperor then patted his knee and sighed:ğŸ”½The laity are confused about the distant principles.
Monastics are stuck in the immediate teachings.
Those who are confused by the distant truth call it empty talk.
Those who are stuck in the near teaching are constrained by the chapters.
As for what Dharma Master Vasubandhu said, it is truly enlightening and clear.
One can discuss it with him at the level of humans and gods.
He was then ordered to stay at Jetavana Temple with abundant offerings.
He translated the above-mentioned sutras, treatises, records, etc. on a regular basis.
He stayed at Dinglin Temple during the summer retreat.
At that time, a believer spread out a mat of flowers.
Only the flowers under where Vasubandhu sat became even more fresh.
The assembly was all amazed.
Later, he returned to Jetavana and suddenly passed away.
Before Vasubandhu passed away, he wrote a farewell text in advance.
It was a thirty-six-line verse.
He himself said he had attained the second fruit.
He entrusted it to his disciple Ashvaghosa, saying:
After my death, you can show this text to the monks of India and the people of this land.
Moreover, when Vasubandhu died, the assembly all saw an object shaped like a dragon.
It was one chang long.
Directly above the corpse in the sky.
His last verse said:
Previously bowing to the Three Jewels,
The pure precepts and all the elders,
In the turbid world there are many flatterers and sycophants,
Empty and false, without sincerity or trust.
Foolish and deluded, not recognizing the truth,
Bearing jealousy and slighting those with virtue.
Therefore, all the sages and saints,
In this world they conceal their traces.
I, Guá¹‡abhadra,
When my life is about to end,
The wholesome merits I have attained,
I will now speak truthfully.
Not with a flattering mind,
Hoping to seek fame and profit,
In order to encourage the lazy,
To increase the Buddha's teachings.
The great Dharma power is like this,
All of you listen attentively.
In the past, in the wilderness,
I first contemplated a corpse,ğŸ”½Swollen, with maggots and rotting,
Stinking, with pus and blood flowing.
Focusing the mind on that place,
The nature of this body is like this.
Always seeing this bodily appearance,
Like a moth, not fearing the fire.
In this way, immeasurable kinds.
Cultivating the contemplation of a corpse,
Abandoning other heard wisdoms,
Relying on the forest and trees,
In the night, single-mindedly diligent,
Correctly contemplating, never forgetting,
The object always in front,
Just like facing a clear mirror.
Just as in them, so am I.
Thus the mind is tranquil and still,
The body transformed, extremely clear and pure.
Cool and refreshing, this is bliss,
Increasing great joy,
Then giving rise to an unattached mind,
Transforming into the appearance of a skeleton,
The white bones present in front,
Rotten and separated at the joints,
The white bones all ground to extinction,
Stainless wisdom blazing,
Taming the appearance of the contemplated Dharma,
At that time, I attained this,
The body at ease, extremely supple.
Cultivating in this way,
The superior progress increases and grows,
The dust particles moment by moment extinguished,
Destroying form, abiding in right mindfulness,
This is the ultimate of the body,
What conditions give rise to craving?
Knowing that they arise from various delusions,
Like a fish greedy for bait,
They and immeasurable destructions,
Moment by moment, contemplated as decaying,
Knowing their basis,
Arising from the mind's monkey,
Karma and the fruits of karmic retribution,
Dependent on conditions, moment by moment ceasing,
The mind's various knowledges,
Are not the characteristics of separate dharmas,
This is then the mindfulness of applied thought,
Gradually fulfilling cultivation,
Contemplating various dharma characteristics,
The mind becomes increasingly clear.
In that eon,
I clearly saw the four establishments of mindfulness,
Faithful practice from the realm of objects,
Concentrating the mind, abiding in the middle,
Suffering like a blazing sword,
This is caused by the turning of craving,
The end of craving is like nirvana,
Universally seeing the three realms,
The body extremely emaciated by the blazing flames of death,
Joyfully enjoying the skillful means,
The body gradually fills out again,
The excellent and wondrous characteristics arise,
The topmost forbearance is also like this,
This arises in my mind.
The true and proper expedient means.
Gradually reducing the scope of objects.
The bliss of quiescence grows.
Attaining the supreme worldly dharmas.
In one thought, one conditions the truth.
The subsequent acceptance of the Dharma arises.
This is called the uncontaminated path.
False appearances and various objects.
Names are all far removed.
The meaning of the truth of the object.
Eliminating afflictions and attaining coolness.
Accomplishing the fruit of samÄdhi.
The cause of coolness free from defilements.
Neither rising nor sinking.
Wisdom is pure like the sun.
Tranquil and rightly abiding.
The pure mark of quiescence.
This is not what I proclaim.
Only the Buddha can attest to it.
The Abhidharma of the NÄgas.
Explains the five causes and effects.
Knowing and practicing the true meaning.
The name cannot be seen.
The treatises explain different tenets.
The principle of practice is non-dual.
Biased attachment has right and wrong.
The enlightened have no disputes.
Cultivating various wondrous characteristics.
I do not proclaim them now.
Fearing people will give rise to false thoughts,
Deceiving and confusing the world.
Regarding the cultivation of beneficial characteristics,
I have already explained a small part.
If there are those who understand well,
They will understand this dependent origination.
In the borderlands of the country of MarÄva,
I first attained the initial holy fruit.
In the mountain temple of Ä€rÄá¸a,
I secluded myself and cultivated detachment.
Later, in the country of Siá¹ƒhala,
In the village named Kapila,
I further cultivated and attained the second fruit,
Which is called saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin.
From this point on, there were many difficulties,
Obstructing the cultivation of the path of detachment from desire.
Seeing me cultivating detachment,
Knowing this place was secluded,
Everyone gave rise to a rare mind,
And offerings came in competition.
I saw them as like fire and poison,
And my mind gave rise to great disgust.
Avoiding the chaos, I floated on the sea,
To the countries of ÅšrÄ«ká¹£etra and Lin'yi.
Blown by the winds of karmic action,
Following conditions to the Song realm.
In all the countries,
according to their abilities, they promoted the Buddha-Dharma.
Without asking what should be asked,
they contemplated the truth with true reality.
Now, this body is extinguished,
still like a lamp going out.

It is seen in the records of Dao-hui, Song and Qi dynasties. The Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharma Há¹›daya ÅšÄstra in twelve fascicles, translated together with BodhiyaÅ›as. The Laá¹…kÃ¢vatÄra SÅ«tra in four fascicles, translated in the twentieth year of the Yuanjia era.

The Sutra of Past and Present Causes and Effects in four fascicles, translated at Xin Temple in Jingzhou.
This is the third version.

It is largely the same as the original version of the Sutra of the Buddha's Past and Present Life translated by Zhu Dayu in the Han Dynasty and Qian in the Wu Dynasty, with slightly different wording. It is found in the records of Shi Xing, Seng You, Li Kuo, and others. The Sutra on the Sixty-two Views in four fascicles, found in a separate record. The record of Seng You says it is in one fascicle. The Sutra of the Great Expansive Jeweled Casket in three fascicles, found in the record of Li Kuo. The Sutra of the Names of Present Buddhas in three fascicles. On the seventh day of the first month in the twenty-ninth year of the Yuanjia era,
it was translated at Jingzhou for Prince Liu Yixuan of Nanqiao.
It is also called the Sutra of the Names of Present Buddhas with Blooming Flowers.

It is found in the record of Shi Xing and the Biographies of Eminent Monks. The Tripiá¹­aka Master from Central India, Guá¹‡abhadra.
In Chinese, it means Virtuous Merit.
Skilled in the study of the MahÄyÄna.
People of the time also called him MahÄyÄna.
It is also called YÇn.
In the 12th year of the Yå…ƒå˜‰ era, he arrived in Yangdu.
The emperor deeply revered him.
Liu Yikang, Prince of Pengcheng, and Liu Yixuan, Prince of Nanqiao,
both studied under him.
He was ordered to reside at Qiyuan Temple.
He was also invited to translate the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢gama and other texts.
Baoyun translated the language.
Huiquan took notes.
Later, he followed Prince Qiao to govern Jingzhou.
He again translated the Sutra of King Asoka and other sutras at Xin Temple.
The sutras he translated before and after totaled over 100 scrolls.
Most of them were translated by his disciple Fayong.
Prince Qiao once invited him to lecture on the Flower Ornament Sutra.
Vasubandhu himself thought he was not yet proficient in the Song language and felt ashamed.
He then single-mindedly repented day and night,
requesting AvalokiteÅ›vara to respond to his prayers.
He then dreamed of a person in white clothes holding a sword and holding the head of a person in front of him, saying:
Why are you worried?
Vasubandhu then bowed his head and told him his intention.
The person replied:
Do not worry too much.
He then used the sword to replace Tanguo's head with a new one.
He told him to turn around and then asked, Do you feel any pain?
Tanguo replied, I feel no pain.
He suddenly felt his mind and spirit filled with joy.
In the morning, he arose and fully understood the meaning of the Sanskrit words.
He then lectured on the sutra, his eloquence flowing like a river.
Later, he returned to Yangdu.
At the emperor's banquet, all the princes and officials were present.
The emperor ordered to see Tanguo, but he had not yet washed his hair, so his white hair was stark.
The emperor looked from afar and said to Xie Zhuang and others, The MahÄyÄna master is intelligent and quick-witted.
But his old age is approaching.
I will try to ask him.
His words will surely be able to enlighten people's minds.
Tanguo ascended the steps.
The emperor welcomed him and said, The MahÄyÄna master, today you have not failed in your intention to come from afar.
From the outside, what is there? There is only one in the MahÄyÄna.
The master immediately replied, ğŸ”½The great vehicle is vast and boundless,
I have long admired the teachings and come to the imperial capital from afar.
I have received offerings for nearly thirty years.
The emperor's grace and favor are deeply appreciated.
But now, at seventy years old, I am old and sick.
I have no more time left, only death.
The emperor greatly admired and delighted in his quick wit and eloquence.
He ordered Dharmaká¹£ema to sit close to the imperial seat.
The entire court looked on with admiration and praised him.
He was also skilled in spells.
